awd_titl_txt: I-Corps Sites: Type II - University of Nevada Las Vegas (UNLV) Lean Entrepreneurship Advancement Program (LEAP)
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, from the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, extends their NSF I-Corps Site for scale up to their next phase of support for innovation and entrepreneurship. Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors. This is a proposal for a Type II I-Corps Site. Type II proposals are submitted by institutions that have already received a Type I award.

The University of Nevada, Las Vegas continues operation of the Lean Entrepreneurship Advancement Program (LEAP) to aid commercialization of student, faculty and community innovations. The I-Corps Site committee utilizes the resources and expertise of the Troesh Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation (TCFEI), the Division of Research and Economic Development (DREC), and the Mendenhall Innovation Program (MIP) to execute the LEAP at UNLV. Type II funding will allow the program to fund the increasing number of I-Corps teams due to the rapidly changing commercialization environment at UNLV and the region.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF REGENTS OF NEVADA SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
When UNLV was first awarded a I-Corps Site Grant in 2016 There were four major goals presented by the Co-PI from the Lee Business School and the Howard Hughes College of Engineering.  Those four major goals were: 

 

The first major goal of the NSF I-Corps Grant program was to enhance the already highly successful collaboration between the Lee Business School and the College of Engineering as well as to generate collaborations with additional centers, colleges, and institutes across campus to increase the number of projects in the technology commercialization pipeline.

 

Another major project goal was to facilitate the use of Lean Launchpad (LLP) principles through the addition of for credit classes, workshops, and programs across campus to promote commercialization activities among faculty and students.

 

 Another goal was to leverage the entrepreneurial ecosystem that has developed in Las Vegas both on and off campus to commercialize projects that would help create a more diverse economic base in southern Nevada.

 

Finally, the last major goal was to increase the number of underrepresented individuals participating in entrepreneurial activities.

 

To say these goals were achieved and more would be an understatement.   Here are just a few things have have been accomplished at UNLV since the original site award in 2016:

 

  • Over 4000 students and faculty now exposed to Lean Launch Pad tools 

  • UNLV has been designated an R1 Research University by The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Higher Education

  • UNLV Tech Park building is now complete and more commercialization efforts are being provided as a result.  ( http://unlvtechpark.com/ )

  • Black Fire Innovation was created to support innovation in the hospitality space and provides support to I-Corps teams (https://www.unlv.edu/econdev/black-fire-innovation)

  • Some I-Corp teams displayed their prototypes on the UNLV CES Booth each year

  • New UNLV incubator developed to support teams after participation in I-Corps (https://www.unlv.edu/econdev/innovation)

  • Rebel Forge was created to provide students with individualized counseling for their business opportunities (https://www.unlv.edu/econdev/rebelforge)

  • $300,000+ in additional funds were raised for the Rebel Venture Fund (a student start up investment fund where students decide which opportunities they would like to invest in).

  • An additional $350,000 was raised by joining the Blackstone Launchpad to support entrepreneurship on campus.

  • Troesh Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation hosted the 2020 Global Consortium of Entrepreneurship Centers Conference (GCEC).  The I-Corps site program played a role in the credibility of the university to host the conference.  The 2020 conference was hosted virtually due to the pandemic.  We also hosted in person in 2022 on campus with over 600 attendees.

  • UNLV is listed by US News and World Report as the Nation's Most Diverse Campus and those participating in UNLV's site program are most often from underrepresented groups.

  • UNLV President Keith Whitfield has created the President?s Innovation Challenge which is a multidisciplinary team competition encouraging social and business entrepreneurship to help solve major problems of our day in Southern Nevada and beyond.

  • UNLV along with its partner institutions has been awarded the NSF I-Corps HUB grant that created the Desert Pacific HUB.

 

Innovation and entrepreneurship are now major initiatives at UNLV and we play a more significant role in the local entrepreneurial ecosystem.  If the original Co-Pi?s would have known how different the university would look just 6 years after they were awarded the Site Grant and the role that grant played in the process, I think they would have been very proud of the catalyst that I-Corps was for UNLV.


 

 


Last Modified: 04/27/2023
Modified by: Leith Martin
por.por_txt_cntn:
When UNLV was first awarded a I-Corps Site Grant in 2016 There were four major goals presented by the Co-PI from the Lee Business School and the Howard Hughes College of Engineering.  Those four major goals were: 

 
The first major goal of the NSF I-Corps Grant program was to enhance the already highly successful collaboration between the Lee Business School and the College of Engineering as well as to generate collaborations with additional centers, colleges, and institutes across campus to increase the number of projects in the technology commercialization pipeline.

 
Another major project goal was to facilitate the use of Lean Launchpad (LLP) principles through the addition of for credit classes, workshops, and programs across campus to promote commercialization activities among faculty and students.

 
 Another goal was to leverage the entrepreneurial ecosystem that has developed in Las Vegas both on and off campus to commercialize projects that would help create a more diverse economic base in southern Nevada.

 
Finally, the last major goal was to increase the number of underrepresented individuals participating in entrepreneurial activities.

 
To say these goals were achieved and more would be an understatement.   Here are just a few things have have been accomplished at UNLV since the original site award in 2016:

 


Over 4000 students and faculty now exposed to Lean Launch Pad tools 


UNLV has been designated an R1 Research University by The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Higher Education


UNLV Tech Park building is now complete and more commercialization efforts are being provided as a result.  ( http://unlvtechpark.com/ )


Black Fire Innovation was created to support innovation in the hospitality space and provides support to I-Corps teams (https://www.unlv.edu/econdev/black-fire-innovation)


Some I-Corp teams displayed their prototypes on the UNLV CES Booth each year


New UNLV incubator developed to support teams after participation in I-Corps (https://www.unlv.edu/econdev/innovation)


Rebel Forge was created to provide students with individualized counseling for their business opportunities (https://www.unlv.edu/econdev/rebelforge)




$300,000+ in additional funds were raised for the Rebel Venture Fund (a student start up investment fund where students decide which opportunities they would like to invest in).


An additional $350,000 was raised by joining the Blackstone Launchpad to support entrepreneurship on campus.


Troesh Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation hosted the 2020 Global Consortium of Entrepreneurship Centers Conference (GCEC).  The I-Corps site program played a role in the credibility of the university to host the conference.  The 2020 conference was hosted virtually due to the pandemic.  We also hosted in person in 2022 on campus with over 600 attendees.


UNLV is listed by US News and World Report as the Nation's Most Diverse Campus and those participating in UNLV's site program are most often from underrepresented groups.


UNLV President Keith Whitfield has created the President?s Innovation Challenge which is a multidisciplinary team competition encouraging social and business entrepreneurship to help solve major problems of our day in Southern Nevada and beyond.


UNLV along with its partner institutions has been awarded the NSF I-Corps HUB grant that created the Desert Pacific HUB.



 
Innovation and entrepreneurship are now major initiatives at UNLV and we play a more significant role in the local entrepreneurial ecosystem.  If the original Co-Pi?s would have known how different the university would look just 6 years after they were awarded the Site Grant and the role that grant played in the process, I think they would have been very proud of the catalyst that I-Corps was for UNLV.
